Evidence: Report notes many newcomers are keenly interested in sport and physical activity but are not participating due to multiple barriers, despite a general desire to be active.
ICC (2014) concludes that the barriers cited by new citizens are mainly structural challenges rather than cultural issues.

Overview of the Barriers page lists 12 barriers: financial, transportation, time commitment, organizational policies, unfamiliarity with sport, lack of information, language, competing interests, political/cultural, integration, perceptions of sports, racism.
Sports can present financial barriers when fees, equipment, and facility costs are high, especially for families focused on housing, work, and school in early settlement years.

Solutions include subsidies, slush funds, free programs, varied price points, instalment payments, and equipment banks; promising practices list KidSport, Jumpstart, Comrie’s Sports Equipment Bank, municipal subsidy schemes.
Families may lack cars, face inconvenient schedules, or find public transit costs/time prohibitive; some are uncomfortable asking for carpooling support.

Solutions include carpool systems, bus rentals, transit tokens, funding for transit; examples include free transit passes for refugees, free child fares, grants that include bus tickets, and bike programs for newcomer youth.
Sports may demand too much time for working families adapting to life in a new country; lack of time is cited as a major barrier for both new and established Canadians.
Solutions highlight drop-in programs at varied times, school-based offerings, and clear communication of true time commitments including hidden volunteer expectations.

Newcomers may not know how sports are organized in Canada; information may be incomplete, hard to access, or full of unfamiliar terminology, and online-only systems or credit-card-only payment can be barriers.
Solutions include governing bodies acting as hubs, plain-language materials, multi-sport or multi-movement events, and partnerships with municipalities and schools to simplify access.
Many newcomers are unfamiliar with Canadian sports and need basic introductions to rules and skills before they can feel confident and want to continue.
The guide recommends free clinics, drop-ins, learn-to programs, open houses, and mentoring to build basic skills and confidence; multiple promising practices illustrate these approaches.
There is a general lack of information on how to get involved and what assistance programs exist, especially for newcomers.
Solutions emphasize partnerships with settlement agencies, schools, libraries, religious centres, and use of plain-language orientation packages and central phone/311 systems.
Language barriers make it hard to register, find information, complete paperwork, and communicate with leaders during programs.
The guide advocates translated materials, interpreters at practices, varied communication channels, and using multilingual coaches or community champions to support participation.
Newcomers may prioritize education, work, and language/cultural learning over sport, so they may not formally engage even if programs exist.

Solutions recommend educating families on sport’s benefits for health, belonging, community connectedness, and academic performance, and using after-school programs and school boards to build physical literacy.
Political and cultural clashes from countries of origin may follow newcomers and shape who they are willing to play with and against.
The report recommends cultural humility training, attention to religious festivals, understanding intra-community politics, and, where needed, gender-separated programs with same-gender leaders.
Newcomers may choose teams of people from their own country of origin rather than mainstream leagues because of comfort and familiarity.
Integration solutions include gateway associations, programs like Football Hockey Link, and community partnership networks that bridge newcomers into mainstream sport systems.
Some sports (e.g., hockey) are perceived as too aggressive, violent, or expensive based on community narratives and misinformation.
The guide suggests education on safety rules, showcasing safe play, and offering adapted versions such as flag football or wheelchair basketball to address fears and broaden access.
Newcomers may experience racism in sport and feel unwelcome, especially in programs with few other newcomers; aquatic sports are cited as having very few racially diverse champions.
Solutions include zero-tolerance racism policies, Respect in Sport training, proactive recruitment of diverse talent, and showcasing diversity in events, marketing, and testimonials.

Physical literacy is defined as motivation, confidence, competence, knowledge, and understanding to engage in physical activity for life; it is presented as the foundation for Active for Life and Excellence.

The Sport for Life Framework includes added considerations of Awareness and First Involvement specifically to help those not engaged early in life, including newcomers, have positive initial experiences.

Quality sport is described as developmentally appropriate, participant-centered, progressive and challenging, planned, inclusive, fun, fair, holistic, and safe; a checklist is provided to operationalize this.
True Sport and HIGH FIVE® are highlighted as national initiatives supporting inclusive, values-based, child-centred quality sport and welcoming of diversity.

The guide proposes a structured action plan: create a vision, scan people/places/programs, plan-activate-evaluate, set targets, engage funders, and create advisory committees with newcomer representation.
Repeated emphasis is placed on partnerships between sport organizations, municipalities, schools, settlement agencies, and community groups to share resources and improve inclusion.
The action framework explicitly includes evaluation and research to measure impact over 12 months, 2 years, 5 years and to refine programs.

While barriers and solutions are richly described and many examples are listed, the guide is largely qualitative and does not systematically quantify outcomes across programs, limiting precise comparative measurement.
